SENT.plain: Surveillance methods in Barrett esophagus (BE) using light microscopic examination of random biopsy specimens may miss focal dysplasia
In addition, dysplastic foci identified initially may not be relocated subsequently, making chemoprevention studies difficult
By using a special gastroscope, systematic mapping (4-quadrant biopsy specimens at 1-cm intervals) was performed in 22 patients (33 total mappings yielding 700 biopsy specimens)
H&E, immunohistochemistry, and DNA ploidy analysis were performed
c-erbB-2 and positive Ki-67 were detected only in dysplastic sites; thus, their detection did not precede morphologically identifiable dysplasia
On the other hand, aneuploidy and p53 were detected in dysplastic and nondysplastic areas
p53 was correlated with dysplasia, and S-phase narrowly missed correlation, while aneuploidy was not correlated
PCNA and bcl-2 were ubiquitous, limiting their usefulness
On second maps, epithelial type was reidentified with 81% accuracy
A significant correlation was found between p53 and dysplasia
Sites of dysplasia and abnormal biomarkers could be relocated accurately by using endoscopic mapping
Therefore, mapping combined with biomarker studies may provide better surveillance and serve as a useful technique in chemoprevention studies
